newsitem.title: USA: US OPTIONS FOCUS/Market off but maybe not for long.
newsitem.headline: US OPTIONS FOCUS/Market off but maybe not for long.

text.p: U.S. stocks were suffering from some long-delayed profit-taking Wednesday but options analysts and traders said the pressure may not last.
"The market's attempting to go down and it will probably fail once again," said one options dealer in Chicago. "There's some profit-taking."
He said a moderate exercise of S&P 100 index .OEX call options Tuesday may have put pressure on the market. Nearly 2,000 OEX calls were exercised Tuesday
"It's been an awfully good rally and it looks like people are waiting to buy," he added.
By about 1115 CDT/1615 GMT, the bellwether Dow industrial average .DJI was down 44 points at about 7,717.
The broader S&P 500 index .SPX was off 5.35 at 889.07 and September S&P 500 futures lost 4.55 to 898.20.
The spot OEX index fell 5.20 to 867.68.
Michael Schwartz, a managing director at Oppenheimer & Co, said it was early to tell whether this week's expiration of June options would put upside or downside pressure on the market.
But he noted that the heaviest open interest in S&P 500 options was in in-the-money calls, a potentially bullish sign.

"The biggest open interest is all in deep in-the-money calls on the SPX," he said. "If this statistic maintains itself into Thursday night, it bodes well for a big buy imbalance on the opening" Friday.
OEX options are American-style, which means they can be exercised any time up to expiration but SPX options are European-style, which means they can only be exercised at expiration.
If a lot of deep in-the-money SPX calls remain open through Thursday's close, chances are good they will be exercised Friday morning, which could push the market higher.

Some investors exercising Friday morning would likely have to buy stock or futures because they would not be covered "or don't want to lose their stock," said Harrison Roth, a first vice president at Cowen & Co.
He added that typically, whatever happens in the market on an expiration Friday is reversed the following Monday.
"I never know what's going to happen but I have a good idea this time," he said. "There's going to be huge volume."
Traders have noted that open interest in OEX, SPX and SPX futures options remains fairly high ahead of the expiration, which could boost volume and which some view as bullish.
The dealer in Chicago said much of Wednesday's major index activity was linked to the expiration.
"We've got some squaring up going on before the expiration," he said. "Usually it happends on Wednesday now, maybe Thursday morning.
"By Friday, everything will be fairly quiet."
((Gregory Crawford, 312 408 8750))
E-mail: derivatives@reuters.com
